title: Only four Man City players survived Leicester humiliation
text:
Sport Only four Man City players survived Leicester humiliation Claudio Ranieri has played a significant part in the direction of Manchester City over the last 12 months Share Click   Pep Guardiola dismisses the art of tackling Share this video Get Manchester City FC   Thank you for subscribing!   
However Claudio Ranieri is remembered by Leicester fans, Manchester City owe him a debt of gratitude. 
Not once, but twice in 2016, the now-sacked Tinkerman helped point the Blues in the right direction - by giving them a thumping . 
Back in February, a home game at the Etihad allowed the opportunity for order to be restored to the footballing world. 
A City win would have dethroned the Foxes at the top of the table, asking the most serious question of their title challenge and in the meantime boosting the ego of a manager who had days earlier announced his own sacking in typically awkward fashion. 
It never looked on from the first whistle. 
Leicester coasted to victory to give their fairytale further momentum and show how badly City had fallen asleep at the wheel under Manuel Pellegrini. 
December's meeting between the teams was arguably more important. 
Pep Guardiola's arrival in Manchester was already a done deal when a Robert Huth double undid the Blues, yet his masterplan was wavering four months into the season. 
It wasn't a crisis - City could have gone top of the league a week earlier if they had beaten Chelsea. 
But the manner of that defeat left questions, and the thumping they got at the King Power Stadium after a bewildering defensive performance amped up the scrutiny - especially when Guardiola talked tackling and immediately following the game. Read More 
That 90 minutes prompted a major turnaround from the coach. 
Training sessions were altered to focus on winning second balls, and the three man defence was shelved. 
As he would go on to say about his methods: "I believed we had it and they (the players) did not believe we had it." 
Just as significant have been the personnel changes. 
Only four of the XI that lined up against Leicester were in the team against Monaco. 
Injuries and suspensions partly account for that - but Fernando, Kelechi Iheanacho and Jesus Navas have been relegated to the fringes since, and Claudio Bravo was a big casualty. Read More
